title: Evidence Request Bank development
abstractText:
This one-year feasibility study led by the Centre for Research on Families and Relationships (CRFR) will explore and establish an Evidence Request Bank to produce and share appraised summaries of evidence for the voluntary and public sectors, in direct response to their practice needs.This fills a gap, opening up the evidence base for delivering public and voluntary services, particularly around early years, social care and other areas of potential preventative work. It creates a channel for partnership development and shared service development.

The evidence bank will respond to requests for reviews of evidence from practitioners or policy-makers in the partner organisations:

  • Children in Scotland
  • Parenting Across Scotland
  • West Lothian Council.

The process is as follows:

  • define topic area and research questions for each review with the relevant partner,
  • CRFR carry out the review and write up the evidence in plain language,
  • peer review the scope and findings of the review through a panel of academic and user reviewers
  • the partnership discuss the Evidence Request findings and share it more widely with others interested in the topic
  • partners use the evidence to inform practice, policy and service developments as appropriate.

Partnership funding has also been obtained from The Scottish Government.
impactText:
This project delivered synthesised evidence to three partners who have used it extensively to:
1) develop support for transition between primary and secondary school in a local authority
2) Develop training for the children's workforce
3) Inform voluntary sector organisations about the changing nature of family life and implications for services Communities and Social Services/Policy,Education Societal,Policy & public services
findingsText: Understanding and having access to reliable evidence of what might work is essential to the delivery of services in the public and voluntary sectors. Working with our partners who deliver services and policies for the children and families sector we developed and piloted a model for delivering evidence to practitioners and policy makers. A range of issues were considered including: whether the evidence met the needs of the requester; value for money and affordability; desirable features and products; tools and processes; timescales and ERB capacity regarding supply/demand. The four partner organisations are all continuing to use the evidence delivered under this project. West Lothian Council and The Scottish Government are using the review on transitions between nursery and primary school to inform their work with the Early Years Collaborative. Parenting Across Scotland are using the demographic report on families to develop services. Children in Scotland are using both reports to develop and deliver their training programme.
